natural problem: Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
natural solution: It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.

So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "nat list"
and nth_digit :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "alberts_list = [x \<leftarrow> [1..]. (first_digit x = 1)]"
and h1 : "length (take 1000 (concat (map digit_list alberts_list))) = 1000"
shows  "nth_digit 998 = 1 \<and> nth_digit 999 = 1 \<and> nth_digit 1000 = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "nat list"
and nth_digit :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "alberts_list = [x \<leftarrow> [1..]. (first_digit x = 1)]"
and h1 : "length (take 1000 (concat (map digit_list alberts_list))) = 1000"
shows  "nth_digit 998 = 1 \<and> nth_digit 999 = 1 \<and> nth_digit 1000 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Albert has a list of numbers that start with the digit 1. He writes down the first 1000 digits of this list. Find the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits of the sequence. The final answer is 998th digit = 1, 999th digit = 1, and 1000th digit = 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "int list" and alberts_digits :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "alberts_list = [x \<leftarrow> [1..]. length (show x) > 0 \<and> hd (digits x) = 1]"
and h1 : "alberts_digits = concat (map digits alberts_list)"
and h2 : "length alberts_digits \<ge> 1000"
shows  "sublist alberts_digits 997 3 = [1, 1, 6]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "int list" and alberts_digits :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "alberts_list = [x \<leftarrow> [1..]. length (show x) > 0 \<and> hd (digits x) = 1]"
and h1 : "alberts_digits = concat (map digits alberts_list)"
and h2 : "length alberts_digits \<ge> 1000"
shows  "sublist alberts_digits 997 3 = [1, 1, 6]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Albert has an infinite list of integers starting from 1, but he only considers the numbers whose first digit is 1. He creates a new list by concatenating the digits of the numbers in his list. What are the 997th, 998th, and 999th digits in his new list? The final answer is [1, 1, 6].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and albert_list :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "albert_list 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> albert_list n = albert_list (n - 1) + 1 \<and> hd(digits(albert_list n)) = 1"
and h2 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 997 = 1"
and h3 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 998 = 1"
and h4 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 999 = 6"
shows  "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 997 * 100 + concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 998 * 10 + concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 999 = 116"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and albert_list :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "albert_list 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> albert_list n = albert_list (n - 1) + 1 \<and> hd(digits(albert_list n)) = 1"
and h2 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 997 = 1"
and h3 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 998 = 1"
and h4 : "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 999 = 6"
shows  "concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 997 * 100 + concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 998 * 10 + concat(map digits (map albert_list [1..<999])) ! 999 = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Albert has a list of numbers, where the first number is 1. For each subsequent number in the list, he adds 1 to the previous number and ensures that the first digit of the new number is also 1. If we concatenate the digits of the numbers in the list up to the 998th number, what is the 997th, 998th, and 999th digit when combined as a three-digit number? The final answer is 116.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
find_last_three_digits_of_list ::
fixes albert_list :: "nat list"
and last_three_digits :: nat
assumes h0 : "albert_list = [n \<leftarrow> [1 ..< \<infinity>]. head_digit n = 1]"
and h1 : "list_length albert_list \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "last_three_digits = albert_list ! 997 * 100 + albert_list ! 998 * 10 + albert_list ! 999"
shows  "last_three_digits = 116"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
find_last_three_digits_of_list ::
fixes albert_list :: "nat list"
and last_three_digits :: nat
assumes h0 : "albert_list = [n \<leftarrow> [1 ..< \<infinity>]. head_digit n = 1]"
and h1 : "list_length albert_list \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "last_three_digits = albert_list ! 997 * 100 + albert_list ! 998 * 10 + albert_list ! 999"
shows  "last_three_digits = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Albert has an infinite list of natural numbers where the first digit of each number is 1. What are the last three digits of the 998th, 999th, and 1000th numbers in this list when combined together? The final answer is 116.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "list_all (\<lambda>n. first_digit n = 1) alberts_list"
and h1 : "sorted alberts_list"
and h2 : "length (take 1000 (concat (map (\<lambda>n. digits n) alberts_list))) = 1000"
shows  "last_three_digits (take 1000 (concat (map (\<lambda>n. digits n) alberts_list))) = 116"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes alberts_list :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "list_all (\<lambda>n. first_digit n = 1) alberts_list"
and h1 : "sorted alberts_list"
and h2 : "length (take 1000 (concat (map (\<lambda>n. digits n) alberts_list))) = 1000"
shows  "last_three_digits (take 1000 (concat (map (\<lambda>n. digits n) alberts_list))) = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Albert has a sorted list of natural numbers where the first digit of each number is 1. He then concatenates the digits of the numbers in this list. Find the last three digits of the first 1000 digits in the concatenated sequence. The final answer is 116.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes albert_list :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. albert_list n = (if n = 0 then 1 else albert_list (n-1) + 1)"
and h1 : "albert_list 998 = 116"
shows  "list_digits_from_998_to_1000 = [1, 1, 6]"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes albert_list :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. albert_list n = (if n = 0 then 1 else albert_list (n-1) + 1)"
and h1 : "albert_list 998 = 116"
shows  "list_digits_from_998_to_1000 = [1, 1, 6]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Albert has a list of numbers, where the first number is 1. Each subsequent number in the list is one more than the previous number. If the 998th number in the list is 116, what are the digits of this number? The final answer is [1, 1, 6].

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes list :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> set list. 1 \<le> n \<and> n < 2000 \<and> (\<forall>k \<in> {0..9}. \<not>(n div 10^3 = k \<and> n mod 10^3 \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "length (filter (\<lambda>n. n div 10^3 = 1 \<and> n mod 10^3 \<noteq> 0) list) = 1000"
shows  "hd (drop 997 list) = 116"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes list :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> set list. 1 \<le> n \<and> n < 2000 \<and> (\<forall>k \<in> {0..9}. \<not>(n div 10^3 = k \<and> n mod 10^3 \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "length (filter (\<lambda>n. n div 10^3 = 1 \<and> n mod 10^3 \<noteq> 0) list) = 1000"
shows  "hd (drop 997 list) = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a list of natural numbers where each number $n$ in the list satisfies the following conditions: $1 \leq n < 2000$, and for all $k$ in the set $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, 9\}$, $n$ does not have a digit $k$ in the thousands place while having a non-zero number in the hundreds, tens, or units place. If there are exactly 1000 numbers in the list where the digit 1 is in the thousands place and the number is non-zero in the hundreds, tens, or units place, find the 998th number in the list. The final answer is 116.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 1000"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<ge> 10. digit_list (k::nat) ! 0 = 1"
shows  "digit_list (n - 2) @ digit_list (n - 1) @ digit_list n = [1, 1, 6]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 1000"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<ge> 10. digit_list (k::nat) ! 0 = 1"
shows  "digit_list (n - 2) @ digit_list (n - 1) @ digit_list n = [1, 1, 6]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the last digit of the 998th, 999th, and 1000th natural numbers when written in sequence. The final answer is [1, 1, 6].

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 998"
shows  "last_three_digits n = 116"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements.  *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 998"
shows  "last_three_digits n = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the last three digits of the number 998. The final answer is 116.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> num. num = 10 ^ (i - 1) + n)"
and h1 : "n = 998"
shows  "n + 1 = 116"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Albert starts to make a list, in increasing order, of the positive integers that have a first digit of 1. He writes $1, 10, 11, 12, \ldots$ but by the 1,000th digit he (finally) realizes that the list would contain an infinite number of elements. Find the three-digit number formed by the last three digits he wrote (the 998th, 999th, and 1000th digits, in that order).
 The final Answer is 116
 ### Proof
 It is clear that his list begins with 1 one-digit integer, 10 two-digits integers, and 100 three-digit integers, making a total of $321$ digits.
 So he needs another $1000-321=679$ digits before he stops. He can accomplish this by writing 169 four-digit numbers for a total of $321+4(169)=997$ digits. The last of these 169 four-digit numbers is 1168, so the next three digits will be $\boxed{116}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> num. num = 10 ^ (i - 1) + n)"
and h1 : "n = 998"
shows  "n + 1 = 116"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a natural number $n = 998$, find the value of $n + 1$. The final answer is $116$.
